questions.question: Question 1: What is the most common site of ectopic testis?
questions.explanation:
The most common site of ectopic testes is the superficial inguinal pouch. Testes develop from the genital ridge in the retroperitoneum at 3 months of intrauterine life. They 
descend into the scrotum by 9 months of age due to differential abdominal growth, pull of the 
gubernaculum, and the effect of testosterone. Cryptorchidism refers to the absence of one or both testes in the scrotal sac. The descent of the 
testis can be arrested in its usual path of descent (true undescended testis) or can migrate from 
the usual path of descent (ectopic testis). The image below shows the possible sites of the testes in cryptorchidism: A retractile testis can also lie in the inguinal canal and needs to be differentiated between an 
ectopic testes. It is present in the scrotum and occasionally moves into the inguinal canal. 990 
Sold by @itachibot An ectopic testis is treated with orchidopexy, while a retractile testis requires no intervention as it 
resolves spontaneously.

questions.question:
Question 2: A 2-month-old infant is brought to the OPD for consultation regarding an empty scrotal sac. 
On examination B/L inguinal masses are palpable. What is the ideal age for orchidopexy in 
this child?
questions.explanation: Orchidopexy is ideally performed before the boy reaches 12 months of age. Orchidopexy is done before 12 months of age to avoid the following complications: • Infertility • Malignancy (Risk may still exist post surgery) • Hernia • Testicular torsion • Infection The management for undescended testes that are not palpable is:

questions.question:
Question 3: A 1-year-old child was brought to the OPD as the mother noticed that the scrotum contained 
only one testicle. On examination, the testis is not palpable in the inguinal region or 
abdomen. A diagnostic laparoscopy reveals abdominal testes and orchiopexy is done. Which 
of the following tumors is most likely to develop in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The tumor most likely to develop in this patient is seminoma. The tumor that develops most commonly in undesceded testes is germ cell tumor in situ or 
intratubular germ cell tumor. It commonly progresses into seminomas. In patients with a nonpalpable testicle, diagnostic laparoscopy is performed. If testis is still not 
visualised, the spermatic cord or testicular artery is traced at the deep inguinal ring to locate it. If a blind ending spermatic cord is found instead, vanishing testis syndrome (or testicular 
regression syndrome) is suspected. It is the partial or total absence of testicular tissue often due to 
an ischemic event in foetal life. 991 
Sold by @itachibot The testis once found can be delivered into the scrotum, and an orchidopexy is performed.

questions.question:
Question 4: 981 
Sold by @itachibot A newborn was diagnosed with undescended testes. Due to the intra-abdominal location of 
the testes, a two-stage Stephen-Fowler’s orchiopexy was planned. Which of the following is 
performed during the first stage of this procedure?
questions.explanation:
In the first stage of a two-stage Stephens-Fowler approach, the testicular vessels are clipped. Clipping of the testicular artery promotes neo vasculogenesis along the vas deferens. It does not 
result in ischemia of the testis due to the presence of collaterals from the cremasteric artery and 
the artery to the ductus deferens (deferential artery). Several months later, after collaterals are established, the second stage is performed during which 
the testis and its new blood supply is mobilized into the scrotum. Stephen-Fowler’s approach is done when an intra abdominal testes is located too far to reach the 
scrotum. Alternatively, Silbar’s orchiopexy may be done. In this procedure, microvascular 
anastomosis of the testicular vessels with internal illiac vessels is done after the testis is mobilised 
to the scrotum.

questions.question: Question 5: What is the most common cause of testicular torsion?

options.b: Presence of remnant of mullerian duct
options.d: Pedicle between epididymis and body of testis

questions.explanation:
High investment of the tunica vaginalis is the most common cause of torsion of testis. It causes 
the testes to hang within the tunica like a clapper in a bell. This is the most common cause of 
testicular torsion in adolescents. Bell clapper testes are typically bilateral. The image below shows the bell-clapper deformity of the 
testes: 992 
Sold by @itachibot Other abnormalities that cause torsion of the testes: • Inversion of the testis: The testis is rotated so that it lies transversely or upside down. • Pedicle between epididymis and body of testis: Separation of the epididymis from the body of the 
testis by a pedicle allows torsion of the testis on the pedicle that connects the testis with the 
epididymis. An appendix testis is a small vestigial appendage located on the upper pole of the testis. Twisting 
of the appendage causes testicular appendix torsion. In it, a classic blue dot sign is seen on the 
upper pole of the testis. It is seen as a hard tender nodule with a blue discoloration on the 
superior aspect of the testis. This is a remnant of the Mullerian duct, that regresses on 
development. The image below shows the blue dot sign on the testis: 993 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 14-year-old boy presents with acute onset of pain in his scrotum. He previously had similar 
pain that would subside spontaneously but the pain this time is unbearable. Physical 
examination shows a swollen erythematous scrotum. Cremasteric reflex is absent. What is the 
next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of testicular torsion. In cases of high clinical suspicion, the 
next best step is to explore surgically. Clinical features of testicular torsion are painful scrotal swelling, erythema, nausea, and vomiting, 
testis seems high in the scrotum and the twisted cord can sometimes be palpated. Signs seen on torsion of the testis are: • Deming’s sign: Spasm of the cremaster muscle due to twisting of the spermatic cord causes the 
affected testis to be positioned higher than the normal testis. • Angell’s sign: The testis on the normal side lies horizontally because of the mesorchium between 
the testis and epididymis. • Cremastic reflex: Absent on the side of the affected testis Doppler ultrasound scanning can confirm the absence of the blood supply to the affected testis, 
but the false positives are high and hence it is not routinely recommended. Manual detorsion of the testes is usually difficult because of acute pain during manipulation. 
Nonoperative manual detorsion is not a substitute for surgical exploration.

questions.question:
Question 7: A child presents with pain and swelling in the right side of his scrotum and testicular torsion 
is suspected. Which is the most appropriate management?

options.a: Immediate exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
options.b: Immediate exploration on symptomatic side only
options.c: Delayed exploration on both symptomatic and asymptomatic side
options.d: Delayed exploration on symptomatic side only

questions.explanation:
In a case of suspected testicular torsion, immediate exploration needs to be done on both the 
symptomatic as well as the asymptomatic side. After the de-torsion, the adequacy of the blood 
flow has to be assessed by Doppler. In testicular torsion, the blood supply to the testicle is compromised due to the twisting of the 
spermatic cord within the tunica vaginalis, resulting in ischemia of the epididymis and the testis. 
The patient usually presents with acute onset pain and swelling of the scrotum. On examination, 
the cremasteric reflex is lost, and the scrotum looks asymmetrical. Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymitis from testicular torsion. Prehn’s sign is said to be 
positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis, and it is seen in epididymo-orchitis. At the time of surgical exploration, contralateral testes also must be explored and fixed to the 
dartos fascia in order to prevent possible torsion occurring in this testes. More than 80% of the testis can be salvaged if surgery is performed within 6 hours. If the testis is 
found to be necrosed on scrotal exploration, orchidectomy of the necrosed testis and orchidopexy 
of the contralateral testis is done.

questions.question:
Question 8: A young man presents to the emergency with a painful scrotum. On examination, the patient 
is febrile and a Prehn’s sign is positive. What is the most likely cause of the patient’s 
condition?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute epididymitis. 994 
Sold by @itachibot A positive Prehn’s sign is used to differentiate epididymis from testicular torsion. A Prehn’s sign is 
said to be positive when the pain gets relieved on lifting the testis. If it persists, it is likely to be 
testicular torsion. Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of acute epididymitis in young, sexually active 
males. In older men(>40yrs) with bladder outflow obstruction, epididymitis results from 
urinary infection, most commonly due to Escherichia coli. Acute epididymitis is managed by antibiotics and scrotal support.

questions.question:
Question 9: A young male patient presented with painless swelling of the scrotum. Examination revealed 
a firm, enlarged epididymis along with beading of the vas deferens. Testes were normal. What 
is the next best step in management?

options.b: Send urine or semen for PCR

questions.explanation:
In the given scenario, a firm enlarged epididymis, beading of the vas deferens, and a normal testis 
on palpation indicate secondary tubercular epididymo-orchitis. The next best step is confirmation 
with polymerase chain reaction (PCR). Beading of the vas deferens is due to subepithelial tubercle formation and is specific to genital 
tuberculosis. A scrotal USG will reveal an enlarged epididymis but does not have diagnostic value. Chest, 
kidney, and upper urinary tract imaging may reveal a primary focus. Tuberculous epididymo-orchitis is usually secondary and resolves once the primary focus is 
treated. Hence, a course of anti-tubercular therapy must be completed even if there is no evidence 
of disease elsewhere. If resolution does not occur within two months, epididymectomy or orchidectomy is advisable.

questions.question:
Question 10: A 57-year-old diabetic patient presented with a painful, malodorous, discolored scrotum as 
shown in the image. The patient was febrile and in extreme pain. Which of the following 
statements is true about his condition? 983 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Managed by antibiotics and scrotal support
options.c: Staphylococcus is the most common causative organism
options.d: The condition is usually self limiting

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Fournier's gangrene in which the testis is classically spared. It lies naked following debridement of the gangrenous skin and is tucked subcutaneously into the 
thigh. It is also called "shameful exposure of the testis." Fournier’s gangrene is a surgical emergency. It is a life-threatening disease, with a mortality of 
over 40% even with treatment. It is due to a mixed infection of both aerobic and anaerobic 
bacterial flora. Concurrent illnesses that diminish the host defense, especially diabetes mellitus and alcoholism, 
predispose patients to the development of Fournier's gangrene. It is managed by debridement, wide surgical excision, IV fluids, and antibiotics.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 24-year-old presents with a scrotal swelling as shown in the image. The swelling is 
brilliantly transilluminant and the testes cannot be palpated separately. Which additional 
clinical finding is most likely to be present?
questions.explanation:
The scrotal swelling is most likely a hydrocele. Due to the movement of fluid, a fluctuation test is 
positive. 995 
Sold by @itachibot Hydrocoele is an accumulation of fluid within the tunica vaginalis. It is brilliantly 
transilluminating and testes will not be separately palpable. As it arises in the scrotum, it is 
possible to get above the swelling. It is irreducible and cough impulse is absent. A USG will show anechoic reflection due to fluid collection.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following is the most common cause of a secondary hydrocele ?
questions.explanation:
A secondary hydrocele is most commonly caused by an acute or chronic epididymo-orchitis. Other 
causes of secondary hydrocele include torsion of the testis and testicular tumors. Primary vaginal hydrocele

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient with hydrocele is scheduled for Lord’s plication. Which of the following is false 
regarding the procedure?

options.a: The procedure can be performed under local anesthesia
options.b: Increased risk of hematoma formation as compared to Jaboulay's
options.c: Preferred for small to medium sized swellings
options.d: Tunica vaginalis is bunched to obliterate the hydrocoele sac

questions.explanation:
Lord's plication has a lower risk of hematoma formation as compared to Jaboulay's procedure. Hydrocele may be managed surgically by various techniques. Lord's plication and Jaboulay's 
eversion of the sac are most commonly performed. Jaboulay's eversion of the sac is preferred for large hydroceles. In this method, the tunica 
vaginalis sac is everted around the testis. Although it has a shorter operative time, the risk of 
hematoma formation is more. Congenital hydroceles are managed by a herniotomy.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 32-year-old male patient presented with a scrotal swelling. On examination, the testis is felt 
separate from the scrotal swelling and the swelling is brilliantly transilluminant, as shown in 
the image below. What is the probable diagnosis? 985 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of a transilluminant scrotal swelling palpated apart from normal testes 
is suggestive of an epididymal cyst. An epididymal cyst is a multilocular cyst formed due to is the cystic degeneration of the 
epididymis. Multiple cysts formed posterior to the epididymis can feel like a bunch of grapes on 
palpation. Due to the presence of crystal clear fluid, an epididymal cyst brilliantly transilluminates 
and has a Chinese lantern appearance. The image shows the Chinese lantern appearance on transillumination: 996 
Sold by @itachibot It can be differentiated from a hydrocele, where the testis is not separately palpable. Option A: Varicoceles present with dragging discomfort in the scrotum on standing and 
characteristic ‘bag of worms’ feel on palpation. Option C: Spermatocele is a unilocular transluminant retention cyst formed at the epididymal 
head. Due to the presence of spermatozoa, barley-water fluid is seen. Although transilluminant, 
the cyst does not have a Chinese lantern appearance. Option D: Chyloceles are formed due to the rupture of lymphatic varix and the discharge of chyle 
into the hydrocele. Fluid rich in cholesterol is seen and the swelling is not transilluminant.

questions.question:
Question 15: A 33-year-old man was referred to the surgery OPD from the infertility clinic. On inspection, 
the scrotum appeared as in the image. On palpation, a bag of worms sensation was felt. What 
is the appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a varicocele. As this patient is young and infertile, 
varicocelectomy is indicated and a Palomo procedure may be performed. Varicocele may present with a dull aching scrotal pain and enlargement. Additionally, patients 
may have infertility. A bag of worms, which gets prominent on Valsalva’s maneuver is palpated 
due to the engorged pampiniform plexus. Often, patients may be asymptomatic and do not require treatment. Left-sided varicocele is more common. Isolated right-sided varicocele should always raise 
suspicion of renal cell carcinoma. (Note: Varicoceles occurs on left side more commonly as the left spermatic vein opens at sharp 
angle to the left renal vein, whereas, on the right side, the right spermatic vein opens into a larger 
Inferior vena cava and an isolated Right-sided varicocele may indicate a tumour that compresses 
the venous return in the inferior vena cava) Treatment of young patients includes surgical ligation of the gonadal vein. It may be achieved 
through embolectomy or varicocelectomy. Approaches to varicocelectomy are: • Inguinal ( Ivanisevic method ) 997 
Sold by @itachibot • Retroperitoneal (Palomo procedure) • Natural orifice transluminal endoscopic surgery through the transvesical route In older patients, NSAIDs and scrotal support are adequate. Grades of varicocel

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not a risk factor for developing testicular carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Benzopyrene exposure is not associated with an increased risk of developing testicular cancer but 
with an increased risk of developing scrotal carcinoma. Shale oil exposure (a petroleum byproduct) is also associated with an increased incidence of 
scrotal carcinoma. Undescended testes, history of contralateral testicular tumor, and Klinefelter's syndrome are 
known to increase one’s risk to develop testicular cancer. Note: Patients with Klinefelter’s syndrome also have an increased risk of developing extragonadal 
germ cell tumors.

questions.question: Question 17: Which among the following are germ-cell tumors?
questions.explanation:
Germ-cell tumors (90–95%) include seminoma, embryonal cell carcinoma, yolk-sac tumor, 
teratoma, and choriocarcinoma. Leydig and Sertoli cell tumors are non-germ-cell tumors.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 45-year-old male patient who presented with a scrotal swelling underwent an orchidectomy. 
The image below shows the histopathology findings. What is your diagnosis? 987 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Based on the gross and microscopic appearance of the specimen, the diagnosis is seminoma. The gross specimen shows a well-circumscribed, pale, gray-white, fleshy, homogenous mass, with 
a lobulated cut surface, usually devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis. Histopathology shows uniform 
tumor cells with abundant clear cytoplasm, distinct cell borders, and large central nuclei. There is 
a sparse lymphocytic infiltrate. Classically, they have a fried egg appearance. Other options: 998 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Yolk-sac tumor has a yellowish-white, mucinous appearance. Histologically, they are 
typically composed of a lace-like (reticular) network of medium-sized cuboidal, flattened, or 
spindled cells, which generally show less cytologic atypia than embryonal carcinoma. In 
approximately 50% of tumors, structures resembling endodermal sinuses (Schiller-Duval bodies) 
may be seen; these consist of a mesodermal core with a central capillary and a visceral and 
parietal layer of cells resembling primitive glomeruli. Option C: Embryonal cell carcinoma appears variegated with foci of hemorrhage or necrosis. 
Histologically, the cells grow in alveolar or tubular patterns, sometimes with papillary folds. More 
undifferentiated lesions may display sheets of cells with cleft-like spaces. The neoplastic cells have 
an epithelial appearance, are large and anaplastic, and have hyperchromatic nuclei with 
prominent nucleoli. The cell borders are usually indistinct, and there is considerable variation in 
cell and nuclear size and shape (pleomorphism). Mitotic figures and tumor giant cells are 
frequently seen. 999 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Teratomas also have a variegated appearance but have cysts reflecting the multiplicity 
of tissue types. Histologically, collections of differentiated cells or organoid structures originating 
in all 3 germ layers can be seen. Elements may be mature (resembling various adult tissues) or 
immature (sharing histologic features with fetal or embryonic tissue).

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following statements is false regarding testicular tumors?

options.a: They may present as an abdominal lump.
options.b: Testicular biopsy is done to diagnose testicular carcinoma.
options.c: Seminomas metastasize predominantly via the lymphatic system.
options.d: Elevated tumor markers are found almost exclusively in non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors.

questions.explanation:
There is no role of testicular biopsy in the diagnosis of testicular tumors. This is due to the risk of 
seeding tumor cells onto the scrotal wall. In testicular tumors, the most common site of lymphatic spread is retroperitoneal lymph nodes 
which may present as an abdominal lump. Elevated tumor markers are found almost exclusively in non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors. 
Few seminomas may have elevated placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP) or beta-human 
chorionic gonadotropin (HCG). Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) can be used as a marker of tumor 
bulk. Seminomas are radiosensitive tumors that metastasize via lymphatics. Non-germ-cell tumors arise 
from Sertoli or Leydig cells and follow a more benign course. Approximately only 10% are 
malignant.

questions.question:
Question 20: A patient with a left-sided testicular tumor is being evaluated for metastasis. Which group of 
lymph nodes is most likely to get involved first?
questions.explanation:
The first sites of metastasis in left-sided testicular tumors are the para-aortic lymph nodes. Testicular tumors metastasize first to the retroperitoneal nodes. Right-sided tumors metastasize 
primarily to the interaortocaval nodes. Left-sided tumors metastasize primarily to the left 
para-aortic nodes. 1000 
Sold by @itachibot Deep inguinal lymph nodes receive drainage from the perineum and lower extremity. Inguinal 
lymph nodes may be involved if the testicular tumor spreads to the skin of the scrotum.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 25-year-old male patient presented with a hard painless testicular lump with a dragging 
sensation. The blood investigations showed raised AFP levels. Which of the following is least 
likely to be included, in further management of this case?

options.c: CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of a non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) of the 
testis. Orchidectomy via a scrotal approach is not done due to fear of seeding the tumor in the 
scrotal skin. Instead, an inguinal approach is used. Raised AFP levels point towards the diagnosis of non-seminomatous germ cell tumor (NSGCT) of 
the testis. Ultrasound of the testis should be done in all suspected cases of testicular tumor. Tumor 
markers (AFP, hCG, LDH) are measured for the staging of cancer. CT of the chest, abdomen, and 
pelvis is done to detect metastasis. Management of testicular tu
